text.p: Queensland premier Rob Borbidge's latest insult to Prime Minister John Howard is all about the terror in the Queensland National Party of the Pauline Hanson bandwagon.
Stating Howard's 10-point Wik plan would "stuff the bush", Borbidge called for explicit extinguishment of native title.
He knows full well Howard cannot go down this track as it would be more certain than ever that such legislation would be rejected by the High Court.
Borbidge is getting in early with a "don't blame me" approach should the fallout in the bush be damaging when the full Howard plan is revealed.
The latest Newspoll, taken after the launch of Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party, showed in Queensland the party was polling the same as the Democrats -- four percent.
But it will not be the Australian Democrats who suffer should One Nation gain a Senate seat, but rather the National Party which could see Senator Bill O'Chee lose his seat.
Hanson has been easily pulling far larger crowds than O'Chee in appearances throughout Queensland.
Hanson's anti-Aboriginal, anti-Asian platform appeals far more to the natural National Party supporter than the supporter of the Democrats.
Four percent is an impressive result for Hanson. But her party is unlikely to win a seat in the Senate unless she stands herself by resigning from her formerly safe Labor seat of Oxley.
The strength of her party is the incredible visibility she has achieved in the comparatively short time she has been in parliament -- just over a year.
But this is also the weakness of her party -- it is a one-woman outfit.

If she stands for the Senate she will almost certainly win in a double dissolution election because of the much lower quota -- 7.7 per cent after distribution of preference votes -- and she will have a good chance in a normal half Senate election even though the quota -- 14.3 per cent -- is much higher.
